choices.text: Handedness develops around 4 years of age
Left-handedness is 3 times more common in twins
Left-handedness is associated with epilepsy and learning disorders more than right handedness
Genius and higher IQ is associated with left-handedness

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT true regarding handedness in children?
questions.solution:
Handedness develops at 3 years of age, while right-left discrimination develops at 4 years of age.

Regarding left-handedness, Illingworth Textbook says that Left-handedness is:

  • 3 times more common in twins (uniovular or binovular) than in singletons
  • More common in epileptics, psychotics and genius people than right-handeness
  • May be associated with immune disease, migraine and learning disorders in some patients.

questions.text: A boy is examined in OPD for short stature. On examination, he was found to have dark, coarse pubic hair with glans developed, pubic hair present, being coarse and curly. However, the pubic hair was absent from the medial surface of thighs. What is the SMR stage in this boy?
questions.solution: SMR staging in boys

choices.text: Observation till 5 years of age, then operate
Transcatheter device closure to be done now
Open Surgical closure to be done now
Start prophylactic antibiotics for recurrent infections and do surgery later

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy with 2 episodes pf pneumonia in last 3 months is evaluated and found to have a wide-fixed split S2. His Echocardiograhy reveals a moderate-sized ostium secundum ASD with Qp:Qs ratio of 2.5:1. What is the management recommended in this child?
questions.solution: Transcatheter device or surgical closure is advised for all symptomatic ASD patients, as well as for asymptomatic patients with Qp:Qs ratio of at least 2 : 1 and those with RV enlargement. The timing for elective closure is usually after the 1st yr of life and before entry into school. For most patients, the procedure of choice is percutaneous catheter device closure using an atrial septal occlusion device, implanted transvenously in the cardiac catheterization laboratory.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy with features of malnutrition, pot-belly and short height was evaluated at an OPD. You noticed the following finding in the child, along with prominent costo-chondral junctions. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: The features are consistent with rickets. The visual image shows widened wrists bilaterally. The child needs to be treated with Vitamin D and evaluated for response.

questions.text: A child develops a rash on face as shown in the picture. There was no fever and the rash responded to topical corticosteroids. His mother is having history of bronchial asthma. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: This is the typical presentation of childhood atopic dermatitis, also called eczema which has a strong familial clustering. Fifth disease presents with fever followed by rash producing a slapped cheek appearance. Sixth disease will have high grade fever for a few days, followed by rash appearing after fever subsides, mainly on the trunk. None of the other options will have a positive family history.

choices.text: IV Broad- Spectrum Antibiotics given after culture reports
IV 5% Albumin preferred over crystalloids, given as 5 ml/kg infusion
IV Normal saline 10-20 ml/kg boluses, given 2-3 times in first hour
IV Ringer lactate 10-20 ml/kg, given 2-3 times in first hour

questions.text: Which of the following is the immediate therapy of choice in a child presenting with septic shock, according to Sepsis-2020 Guidelines?
questions.solution:
As per Sepsis-2020 Guidelines for Pediatric septic shock

  • Start IV Fluid Boluses in case of hypotension
  • Balanced/Buffered Crystalloids preferred over 0.9% Salinei.e. Ringer’s Lactate is preferred over Normal Saline
  • Amount: 40-60 ml/kg in the first hour of management, given as 10-20 ml/kg boluses
  • If the care center does not have an ICU (e.g. PHC), give only 40 ml/kg maximum fluid
  • Avoid colloids like Albumin.
  • Although antibiotics should be started early, one should not wait for culture report and can be given in first hour, after fluid resuscitation has been started

questions.text: A preterm neonate born at 28 weeks developed feed intolerance and abdominal distension. Suspecting necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC), investigations were performed, which revealed gas bubbles in the portal vein. What is the stage during which these finding are first seen in NEC?
questions.solution: Modified Bell's staging for NEC

questions.text: A 25-day-old male infant is brought to emergency with complaints of vomiting, seizures and poor feeding. Examination reveals a micropenis and undescended testis with bifid scrotum. Investigations were ordered and revealed random blood glucose of 28 mg/dl, serum sodium of 126 meq/l, serum potassium of 6.1 meq/l. BUN and serum creatinine were in normal zone. USG revealed cerebriform pattern in both adrenal glands bilaterally. There was history of one previous sibling developing similar problems and dying in infancy. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Key points to examine

  • Male neonate with vomiting, poor feeding and seizures-likely hypoglycemic
  • Ambiguous genitalia
  • Hyponatremia and hyperkalemia with relatively preserved renal functions.
  • USG showing bilateral adrenal glands with cerebriform pattern
  • Positive family history

All these fit into the classic description of congenital adrenal hyperplasia. And male with salt losing crisis and ambiguous genitalia will most likely have 3-beta hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase deficiency among the given options. 21-hydroxylase antibodies can occur in Autoimmune Addison’s Disease in children but will not have similar findings, especially ambiguous genitalia.

Please note that familial glucocorticoid deficiency shows isolated cortisol deficiency and has atrophy of the adrenal glands. Likewise, Wolman Disease shows adrenal calcification.

questions.text: A seven-year-old girl is easily distracted in class and exhibits poor scholastic performance. Seizures are precipitated by hyperventilation, what is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Hyperventilation precipitating absence attacks or vacant staring look, is the classic presentation of absence seizure. Females are more commonly affected and there is associated easy distractibility with poor scholastic performance. DOC is Ethosuximide.

questions.text: Antisense oligonucleotide (ASO) therapy is now available for which among the following neurological disorders?
questions.solution: Nusinersen, marketed as Spinraza, is a medication used in treating spinal muscular atrophy and is a type of anti-sense oligonucleotide. Spinal muscular atrophy is caused by loss-of-function mutations in the SMN1 gene which codes for survival motor neuron (SMN) protein. People survive owing to low amounts of the SMN protein produced from the SMN2 gene. Nusinersen modulates alternative splicing of the SMN2 gene, functionally converting it into SMN1 gene, thus increasing the level of SMN protein in the CNS

choices.text: Acute leukemias occurs about 15-20 times more frequently in Down syndrome than general population
ALL in Down syndrome carries a poor prognosis compared to those in non-syndromic ALL
AML in Down Syndrome carries a poor prognosis compared to those in non-syndromic AML
Methotrexate can cause toxicity when used for therapy in Acute leukemias in Down syndrome

questions.text: Which among the following is not true regarding Leukemia in Down Syndrome?
questions.solution: AML in Down Syndrome is of M7 variety and in general, AML in Down Syndrome is more responsive to chemotherapy, indicating a better outcome than AML in non-DS patients. Other statements are correct.

choices.text: Thyroid dysgenesis is most common cause
Lack of any associated congenital anomaly

questions.text: True statements regarding congenital hypothyroidism include all except?
questions.solution:
• Congenital hypothyroidism is most commonly caused by thyroid dysgenesis in 80-85% cases. Most infants with congenital hypothyroidism are asymptomatic at birth, even if there is complete agenesis of the thyroid gland.
  • Birthweight and length are normal, but head size may be slightly increased because of myxedema of the brain.
  • The anterior and posterior fontanels are open widely; observation of this sign at birth can serve as an initial clue to the early recognition of congenital hypothyroidism.
  • Prolongation of physiologic jaundice, caused by delayed maturation of glucuronide conjugation, may be the earliest sign.
  • Approximately 10% of infants with congenital hypothyroidism have associated congenital anomalies. Cardiac anomalies are most common, but anomalies of the nervous system and eye have also been reported. Infants with congenital hypothyroidism may have associated hearing loss.

questions.text: A neonate delivered at term was noticed to have multiple violet-black macules on the back and thigh since birth, as shown in the picture. Which among the following is true regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
The child is having Mongolian spots.

  • Mongolian spots, also called dermal melanocytosis, appears as blue or slate-gray macular lesions, has variably defined margins.
  • It occurs most commonly in the presacral area but may be found over the posterior thighs, legs, back, and shoulders.
  • The spots may be solitary or numerous and often involve large areas. The incidence of these lesions varies widely across ethnicities, being most common in African-American, Asian, and Hispanic infants (25-80% depending on the study) and less common in white infants (around 6%).
  • The peculiar hue of these macules is a result of the dermal location of melanin-containing melanocytes (mid-dermal melanocytosis) that are presumably arrested in their migration from neural crest to epidermis.
  • They usually fade during the 1st few yr of life as a result of darkening of the overlying skin and do not need any therapy.
  • Malignant degeneration does not occur.

questions.text: Walking up and downstairs with support usually begins at what age?
questions.solution:
Stair walking

  • Crawls/creeps upstairs: 15 months
  • Walking upstairs and downstairs with support: 18 months
  • Walking upstairs without support (2 feet at each step): 24 months
  • Walking upstairs without support (Alternate feet): 30 months
  • Walking downstairs without support (2 feet at each step): 36-42 months
  • Waling downstairs without support (Alternate feet): 44-48 months

questions.text: All of the following are more common in children with Turner Syndrome except?
questions.solution:
Risk of the following is increased in Turner Syndrome

  • Type 2 DM
  • Celiac Disease
  • Autoimmune Hypothyroidism
  • Inflammatory Bowel Disease
  • Recurrent Otitis Media & SNHL
  • Gonadoblastoma: In Mosaics with Y chromosome

questions.text: Which among the following conditions presents in infancy with cycles of cyanosis appearing with a calm, resting child and cyanosis disappearing when the child cries?
questions.solution: Infants with bilateral choanal atresia who have difficulty with mouth breathing make vigorous attempts to inspire, often suck in their lips, and develop cyanosis. Distressed children then cry (which relieves the cyanosis) and become calmer, with normal skin color, only to repeat the cycle after closing their mouths.

questions.text: A three months old HIV positive child following URTI developed sudden onset of breathlessness with intermittent expiratory wheezing. The chest X-ray shows hyperinflation. The O2 saturation was greater than 90%. The treatment of choice is?
questions.solution: URTI followed by dyspnea and expiratory wheezing in an infant is suggestive of Acute Bronchiolitis. CXR showing hyperinflation also confirms the same. Now since the child is HIV positive, Ribavirin needs to be started and hence the answer. According to CDT Pediatrics 2020, patients at risk for life-threatening RSV infections, e.g. children born at < 35 weeks, children with other severe pulmonary conditions, congenital heart disease, neuromuscular disease, or significant immunocompromise) should be considered for RSV prophylaxis therapy. High-risk patients with RSV bronchiolitis may need to be hospitalized and treated with ribavirin.

questions.text: Absolute contraindication for bag and mask ventilation is?
questions.solution: Congenital diaphragmatic hernia is the absolute contraindication while trachea-esophageal fistula is a relative contraindication for bag and mask ventilation. Meconium aspiration is no longer considered to be a contraindication.

choices.text: Breakdown of brown fat with adrenaline secretion

questions.text: All the following can occur in a neonate for heat production except?
questions.solution: Neonates cannot shiver. They mainly produce heat by non-shivering thermogenesis, mediated by lipolysis of brown adipose tissue.

questions.text: Primordial dwarfism implies short stature due to which of the following?
questions.solution: Primordial dwarfism refers to severe short stature seen in children with IUGR and low birth weight, who fail to show catch-up growth by 3 years of age. They can be isolated or syndromic (e.g. Russell Silver Syndrome). Impairment in IGF-1 and IGFBP-2 axis is implicated in some of these patients.

choices.text: An osmotic gap of 200 mOsm/kg rules out osmotic diarrhea

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement regarding osmotic diarrhea in a child?
questions.solution:
Osmotic diarrhoea occurs when non- absorbed nutrients in the GI tract produce an excessive osmotic force pulling water into the bowel lumen.

  • It is often associated with intestinal mucosal damage most commonly seen in older children with lactose intolerance post infectious gastroenteritis. It will therefore stop if the child is fasted.
  • Secretory diarrhoea continues in the fasted state due to alterations in electrolyte fluxes often due to active inflammation.
  • In many cases the diarrhoea is a mixed secretory/ osmotic picture.
  • The stool osmotic gap can be calculated as follows: 
    • Stool osmolality – 2 (Stool Na + K)
  • A low osmotic gap <50mOsm/ kg suggests secretory diarrhoea, high >130mOsm/ kg suggests osmotic diarrhoea.

questions.text: An infant is found to have rash as shown below. Which micronutrient deficiencies can produce such a clinical picture?
questions.solution:
The findings are consistent with a diagnosis of zinc deficiency, as seen in acrodermatitis enteropathica.

  • Acrodermatitis enteropathica is a rare autosomal recessive disorder caused by an inability to absorb sufficient zinc from the diet.
  • The genetic defect is in the intestinal zinc-specific transporter gene
  • Initial signs and symptoms usually occur in the 1st few months of life, often after weaning from breast milk to cow’s milk.
  • The cutaneous eruption consists of vesiculobullous, eczematous, dry, scaly, or psoriasiform skin lesions symmetrically distributed in the perioral, acral, and perineal areas and on the cheeks, knees, and elbows.

questions.text: Which among the following disorders is an example of polygenic inheritance?
questions.solution: Cleft lip/palate shows polygenic/multifactorial inheritance. Fragile X syndrome and G6PD deficiency show X linked recessive, whereas Cystic fibrosis shows Autosomal recessive inheritance.

questions.text: The IEM showing predominant cardiac involvement is?
questions.solution: Pompe disease, also referred to as GSD type II or acid maltase deficiency, is caused by a deficiency of acid α-1,4-glucosidase (acid maltase), an enzyme responsible for the degradation of glycogen in lysosomes. This enzyme defect results in lysosomal glycogen accumulation in multiple tissues and cell types, with cardiac, skeletal, and smooth muscle cells being the most seriously affected. The disease is characterized by accumulation of glycogen in lysosomes. Electrocardiographic findings include a high-voltage QRS complex and a shortened PR interval.

choices.text: Should be present at least for 6 months
Behaviour must be developmentally inappropriate in two or more settings
Should be reported by independent observers
Must begin before 7 years of age

questions.text: Current criteria to diagnose ADHD includes all except?
questions.solution:
ADHD must begin before 12 years of age, according to DSM-5 criteria.

DSM-5 criteria for ADHD:

  • The behaviour must be developmentally inappropriate as compared to normal children of same age.
  • Must begin before 12 years.
  • Must be present for at least 6 months.
  • Must be present in 2 or more settings.
  • Must be reported as such by independent observers.
  • Must not be secondary to another disorder.

Clinical manifestations:

  • Motor restlessness and aggressive, disruptive behavior is seen more commonly in preschool children.
  • Disorganized, distractible, and lack of attention is seen more commonly in older adolescents and adults.

questions.text: Anticipation phenomenon occurs in which of the following?
questions.solution: Anticipation is a pattern of inheritance in which symptoms became manifest at earlier ages and with increasing severity as traits are passed to subsequent generations. The genetic defect in myotonic muscular dystrophy is on chromosome 19 at the 19q13 locus. It consists of an expansion of the DM gene that encodes a serine– threonine kinase (DMPK), with numerous repeats of the CTG codon. Myotonic dystrophy often exhibits a pattern of anticipation in which each successive generation has a tendency to be more severely involved than the previous generation.

choices.text: Rhizomelic shortening of the limbs is characteristic

questions.text: Which of the following is not correct regarding achondroplasia?
questions.solution:
Achondroplasia is an AD disorder. More than half of the cases are due to de novo mutations. This disorder is caused by a common point mutation in Fibroblast Growth Factor Receptor 3 (FGFR3) gene. The mutations in the same gene also cause a lethal dysplasia called thanatophoric dysplasia and a relatively mild dysplasia known as hypochondroplasia.

The clinical manifestations include

  • Short stature with predominant short limbs.
  • There is rhizomelic shortening, large head, frontal bossing, depressed nasal bridge, short and broad trident shaped hands, lumbar lordosis and hypotonia, and delayed motor development.
  • Cognitive development is usually normal.

questions.text: The following non-blanching rash was seen in a child who developed septic shock and tachypnea. The child has an underlying splenic abnormality. This can be due to fulminant infection by?
questions.solution:
In fulminant meningococcal septicemia, the disease progresses rapidly over

several hours from fever with nonspecific signs to septic shock characterized by prominent petechiae and purpura (purpura fulminans) with poor peripheral perfusion, tachycardia (to compensate for reduced blood volume resulting from capillary leak),increased respiratory rate (to compensate for pulmonary edema), hypotension (a late sign of shock in young children), confusion, and coma, resulting from decreased cerebral perfusion.

In this question, presence of splenic abnormality further increases the risk of capsulated bacterial infections like Neisseria meningitides.

questions.text: Most common ocular findings in congenital Zika syndrome include?
questions.solution:
In congenital Zika syndrome, macula and choroid are commonly involved. The most commonly reported macular findings include:

  • Focal pigmentary mottling
  • Chorio-retinal atrophy

questions.text: A 10-month-old infant from rural area presented with pallor, irritability, inability to move his legs, and bleeding gums. The infant is on fresh cow's milk from birth. Of the following, the MOST likely cause of his condition is deficiency of?
questions.solution: Infantile scurvy is manifested by irritability, bone tenderness with swelling, and pseudo paralysis of the legs. The disease may occur if infants are fed unsupplemented cow’s milk in the first year of life or if the diet is devoid of fruits and vegetables. Subperiosteal hemorrhage, bleeding gums and petechiae, hyperkeratosis of hair follicles, and a succession of mental changes characterize the progression of the illness. Anemia secondary to bleeding, decreased iron absorption, or abnormal folate metabolism is also seen in chronic scurvy.

questions.text: All of the following are bioactive substances or growth factors present in breast milk except?
questions.solution: Growth factors present in breast milk and their putative functions

questions.text: In order to discharge from hospital, the minimum weight gain in a severe malnutrition patient should be at least?
questions.solution:
Severely malnourished children are ready for discharge when the child:

  • Is alert and active, eating at least 120-130 kcal/kg/ day with a consistent weight gain (of at least 5 g/kg/ day
  • for 3 consecutive days) on exclusive oral feeding
  • Is receiving adequate micronutrients
  • Is free from infection
  • Has completed immunization appropriate for age
  • The caretaker has been sensitized to home care

choices.text: Hemarthroses are more common than epistaxis in this disorder
Spontaneous recovery within several weeks is expected
Platelet transfusion should be urgently performed
Prothrombin time and activated partial thromboplastin time are prolonged

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl is brought to the office with petechiae and bruising on the face, chest, back, and lower extremities, which her mother noticed early this morning. The mother states that her daughter has been healthy except for a viral upper respiratory illness 2 weeks ago. Laboratory assessment reveals a platelet count of 25,000/microlitre without any splenomegaly. Which of the following statements regarding the likely diagnosis is correct?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis fits into a presentation of acute-onset ITP.

Points to note:

  • Onset of petechia 2 weeks following a viral illness
  • Platelet count showing thrombocytopenia
  • No splenomegaly.

Since there is no mucosal or life-threatening bleeding, only observation is sufficient. There is no role of platelet transfusions in acute ITP. Also note that hemarthroses are a feature of coagulation disorders, not common in platelet disorders. Platelet disorders more commonly show superficial bleeds like petechiae and epistaxis.

questions.text: Maximum concentration of dextrose that can be given through peripheral vein is?
questions.solution: The maximum concentration of dextrose that can be given through peripheral vein is 12.5%. Exceeding this concentration can cause thrombophlebitis.

choices.text: 6 cafe-au-lait macules of size 18 mm in post-pubertal male
3 Lisch nodules in iris on one side

questions.text: Which among the following is not compatible with a diagnosis of Neurofibromatosis-1?
Child builds 5 to 6 blocks at which age?
questions.solution:
Making tower using stacks of cubes:

  • 2-3 cubes: 15 months
  • 4 cubes: 18 months
  • 5-6 cubes: 21 months
  • 7 cubes: 24 months (2 years)
  • 10 cubes: 36 months (3 years)
  • Bridge of 3 cubes: 36 months (3 years)
  • Gate of 5 cubes: 48 months (4 years)

questions.text: Premature fusion of coronal, spheno-frontal and fronto-ethmoidal sutures is seen in-
questions.solution:
• Oxycephaly, also known asTurricephaly, Acrocephaly, Hypsicephaly, Oxycephalia, Steeple head, Tower head, Tower skull, High-head syndrome and Turmschadel, Oxycephaly is the most severe of the craniosynostosis.
  • Early fusion of a combination of the bilateral coronal, sagittal & sometimes lambdoid sutures.
  • Oxycephaly is a form of craniosynostosis that involves the fusion of multiple sutures.
  • The coronal, sagittal & lambdoid sutures are normally involved.
  • This fusion gives a high, conical head with sharp bossing in the region of the anterior fontanelle.

questions.text: A child came with history of fever and respiratory distress. With a suspicion of pneumonia, chest X-ray was ordered (shown below). Which of the following is most likely organism?
questions.solution:
The X-ray image shows thin-walled, air-filled cysts developing

  • Within the lung parenchyma known as 'Pneumatocele'.
  • Pneumatocele can be single emphysematous lesions but are more, often multiple, thin-walled, air-filled, cyst-like cavities.
  • Most often, they occur as a sequela to Acute pneumonia.
  • Most Commonly caused by Staphylococcus aureus.

questions.text: Which among the following is not a clinical manifestation of kernicterus?
questions.solution: Opisthotonus posturing is a feature of acute bilirubin encephalopathy but not seen in kernicterus. Chronic bilirubin encephalopathy (kernicterus) is marked by athetosis, complete or partial sensorineural deafness (auditory neuropathy), limitation of upward gaze, dental dysplasia, and sometimes, intellectual deficits.

questions.text: A 5 year old child presented with multiple petechiae on lower limbs and buttocks and was diagnosed as Henoch-Schoenlein purpura (HSP). Indication to use steroids will be?
questions.solution: Treatment for mild and self-limited HSP is supportive, with an emphasis on ensuring adequate hydration, nutrition, and analgesia. Corticosteroids are most often used to treat significant GI involvement or other life-threatening manifestations. Glucocorticoids such as oral prednisone (1-2 mg/kg/day), or in severe cases, intravenous (IV) methyl prednisolone for 1-2 wk, followed by taper, reduce abdominal and joint pain but do not alter overall prognosis. Corticosteroids are not routinely recommended for prevention of complications such as nephritis.

questions.text: A preterm neonate at 28 weeks developed severe HMD, for which nasal CPAP followed by surfactant was administered using MIST technique. However, due to persistent apneic episodes and pH on ABG below 7.20, the child was intubated and started on mechanical ventilation. Which among the following is the acceptable PaO2 levels to be targeted during mechanical ventilation in this child, ensuring adequate oxygenation and minimal free radical injury?
questions.solution:
The goal of mechanical ventilation in HMD is to improve oxygenation and ventilation without causing pulmonary injury or oxygen toxicity. According to Nelson 21st Ed, acceptable ranges of ABG values vary significantly among institutions but generally recommended target values are as follows:

  • PaO2 50-70 mm Hg
  • PaCO2 45-65 mm Hg (and higher after the 1st few days when risk of IVH is less)
  • pH 7.20-7.35

Also note that ventilation is done in HMD, rates are kept high, ≥ 60/min while the tidal volume is kept low, about 4-6 ml/kg.

questions.text: A child has recently learnt to start walking holding to furniture, as shown in the picture. What is the age at which this milestone is first attained?
questions.solution: Walking holding onto furniture is called Cruising. Cruising first begins at 11 months of age. Walking with support refers to walking with one hand held and usually begins 1-2 months after the onset of cruising, i.e. at 12-13 months of age.

questions.text: An infant had refractory hypocalcemia in first few weeks of life and was diagnosed with congenital hypoparathyroidism. The child was referred to a pediatric cardiologist for further evaluation. Which other clinical manifestation will often be present in such a child?
questions.solution: The features are suggestive of 22q11 deletion syndrome, also called DiGeorge Syndrome. The 22q11 deletion syndrome is characterized by aplasia or hypoplasia of the thymus and parathyroid glands: this results from dysmorphogenesis of the third and fourth pharyngeal pouches during early embryogensis. Other organs that are formed during the same time period are frequently affected as well. Facial abnormalities, esophageal atresia, bifid uvula, and congenital heart disease are some of the anomalies associated with this syndrome. Patients with complete 22q11 deletion syndrome have problems early in life with increased susceptibility to infectious agents such as viruses and fungi. Recurrent candidiasis is a common manifestation in first few months of life.

choices.text: RL bolus @ 20 ml/kg in first hour
NS bolus @ 10 ml/kg in first hour
N/2 Saline in 5% Dextrose @ 30 ml/kg over one hour
RL in 5% Dextrose @ 15 ml/kg over one hour

questions.text: A 4 year old child with Kwashiorkor developed loose stools and presented to Pediatric Emergency with features of severe dehydration and shock. What is the immediate next fluid management to perform in this child in first hour of admission?
questions.solution:
Management of SAM child with shock and severe dehydration

  • Admit the child, ensure oxygenation
  • Ideal fluid: RL in 5% Dextrose. If not available, N/2 saline in 5% Dextrose or simply RL can also be used.
  • In first hour, give 15 ml/kg as infusion over one hour, while doing strict monitoring
  • If child shows improvement, give another 15 ml/kg over next one hour
  • After this, shift to low-osmolarity ORS 5-10 ml/kg/hr either orally or through nasogastric tube
  • In case of poor response at any stage, individualise therapy and consider ionotropic support.

questions.text: A 4-month-old female infant has generalized hypotonia, small ears, inner epicanthal folds, clinodactyly, and wide-spaced first and second toes. For which of the following problems is she most at risk?
questions.solution: The described patient has classical signs and symptoms of trisomy 21. The occurrence of trisomy 21 or Down syndrome increases with advancing maternal age. There is no single physical finding that makes a diagnosis of Down syndrome; rather, the combination of minor and major anomalies often leads to a diagnosis. Among the options given, risk of leukemia is increased in Down syndrome children while risk of solid tumours is relatively low. According to Nelson 21st Ed, Acute leukemia occurs about 15-20 times more frequently in children with Down syndrome than in the general population.

questions.text: A neonate had delayed cry after birth and developed features of hypoxic ischemic encephalopathy (HIE). On examination, he had hypotonia, exaggerated ankle reflex, recurrent focal seizures and miotic pupils. What is the likely stage of HIE according to Sarnat and Sarnat staging system?
questions.solution: The features are suggestive of Stage 2 HIE. Please revise Sarnat and Sarnt staging of HIE as follows:

questions.text: Most common cause of aseptic meningitis in children?
questions.solution: Mumps is the most common cause of aseptic meningitis in children, according to OP Ghai 9th Ed, page 213. Almost 1-10% children developing mumps tend to develop aseptic meningitis. Some children tend to develop full-blown meningoencephalitis. Other manifestations include auditory nerve damage with deafness, cerebellar ataxia, facial neuritis, transverse myelitis and Guillain-Barre syndrome.

choices.text: To plan COVID-19 vaccination to school-going children
To introduce additional vaccination for influenza and pneumococcal
To cover children and pregnant women who missed routine immunization during the COVID-19 pandemic
To provide financial incentives to beneficiaries getting routine immunization at public health centers

questions.text: What is the aim of the recently launched Mission Indradhanush Intensified 3.0?
questions.solution:
Recently, the Intensified Mission Indradhanush (IMI) 3.0 scheme has been rolled out in February 2021 to cover children and pregnant women who missed routine immunisation during the Covid-19 pandemic.

  • It will have two rounds this year which will be conducted in 250 pre-identified districts/urban areas across 29 States/UTs.
  • The districts have been classified to reflect 313 low risk, 152 medium risk and 250 high risk districts.
  • Beneficiaries from migration areas and remote areas would be targeted as they may have missed their vaccine doses during the pandemic.

questions.text: The most common anomalies associated with a trachea-esophageal fistula include?
questions.solution: The most syndrome associated with TEF is VACTERL syndrome (Vertebral anomalies, Anal atresia, Cardiac defects, TE Fistula and Esophageal atresia, Renal and Radial anomalies and Limb defects). Individually, cardiac defects are seen in 38% cases, followed by skeletal defects in 19% cases.

questions.text: Asymmetric moro reflex is seen in all of the following conditions, except?
questions.solution:
Causes of asymmetric moro's reflex

  • Fracture humerus
  • Fracture clavicle
  • Erb's palsy
